title: Ergocalciferol (Vitamin D2) Oral: Uses, Side Effects, Interactions, Pictures, Warnings & Dosing - WebMD
description: Find patient medical information for ergocalciferol (vitamin D2) oral on WebMD including its uses, side effects and safety, interactions, pictures, warnings and user ratings.
cleaned_text: Uses [Vitamin D](https://www.webmd.com/vitamins-supplements/ingredientmono-929-vitamin+d.aspx?activeingredientid=929&activeingredientname=vitamin+d) ( [ergocalciferol](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-8604/ergocalciferol+(vitamin+d2)+oral/details)-D2, [cholecalciferol](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-6152/cholecalciferol+(vitamin+d3)+oral/details)-D3, alfacalcidol) is a helps your body absorb [calcium](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-1575/calcium+oral/details) and phosphorus. Having the right amount of [vitamin D](https://www.webmd.com/vitamins-and-supplements/video/vtamin-d-and-your-health), [calcium](https://www.webmd.com/food-recipes/ss/slideshow-gourmet-calcium), and phosphorus is important for building and keeping strong bones. Vitamin D is used to treat and prevent bone disorders (such as [rickets](https://www.webmd.com/diet/vitamin-d-deficiency), [osteomalacia](https://www.webmd.com/osteoporosis/what-is-osteomalacia)). Vitamin D is made by the body when [skin](https://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/skin-conditions-faq) is exposed to sunlight. [Sunscreen](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-366/sunscreen+topical/details), protective clothing, limited exposure to sunlight, dark [skin](https://www.webmd.com/beauty/nutrients-for-healthy-skin), and age may prevent getting enough vitamin D from the sun.Vitamin D with [calcium](https://www.webmd.com/diet/calcium-food-calculator/default.htm) is used to treat or prevent [bone loss](https://www.webmd.com/osteoporosis/osteopenia-early-signs-of-bone-loss) ( [osteoporosis](https://www.webmd.com/osteoporosis/understanding-osteoporosis-basics)). Vitamin D is also used with other [medications](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) to treat low levels of calcium or phosphate caused by certain disorders (such as [hypoparathyroidism](https://www.webmd.com/women/hypoparathyroidism-rare), pseudohypoparathyroidism, [familial hypophosphatemia](https://www.webmd.com/children/hypophosphatemia-familial)). It may be used in [kidney disease](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/understanding-kidney-disease-basic-information) to keep calcium levels normal and allow normal bone growth. Vitamin D drops (or other [supplements](https://www.webmd.com/men/video/lamm-supplements-diet)) are given to [breast](https://www.webmd.com/women/picture-of-the-breasts)-fed infants because breast milk usually has low levels of vitamin D. How to use VITAMIN D2 Capsule Take [vitamin D](https://www.webmd.com/vitamins-supplements/ingredientmono-929-vitamin+d.aspx?activeingredientid=929&activeingredientname=vitamin+d) by [mouth](https://www.webmd.com/oral-health/anatomy-of-the-mouth) as directed. [Vitamin D](https://www.webmd.com/vitamins-and-supplements/video/vtamin-d-and-your-health) is best absorbed when taken after a meal but may be taken with or without food. Alfacalcidol is usually taken with food. Follow all directions on the product package. If you have any questions, ask your doctor or [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions). If your doctor has prescribed this [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx), take as directed by your doctor. Your dosage is based on your medical condition, amount of sun exposure, diet, age, and response to treatment. If you are using the liquid form of this medication, carefully measure the dose using a special measuring device/spoon. Do not use a household spoon because you may not get the correct dose. If you are taking the chewable tablet or wafers, chew the medication thoroughly before swallowing. Do not swallow whole wafers. If you are taking the rapidly-dissolving tablets, dry your hands before handling the medication. Place each dose on the [tongue](https://www.webmd.com/oral-health/picture-of-the-tongue), allow it to dissolve completely, and then swallow it with [saliva](https://www.webmd.com/oral-health/what-is-saliva) or water. You do not need to take this medication with water. Certain [medications](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) (bile acid sequestrants such as [cholestyramine](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-4803/cholestyramine+light+oral/details)/ [colestipol](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/mono-8111-COLESTIPOL+TABLET+-+ORAL.aspx?drugid=6728&drugname=colestipol+oral), [mineral oil](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-32605/mineral+oil+topical/details), [orlistat](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-17220/orlistat+oral/details)) can decrease the absorption of vitamin D. Take your doses of these medications as far as possible from your doses of vitamin D (at least 2 hours apart, longer if possible). It may be easiest to take vitamin D at [bedtime](https://www.webmd.com/parenting/childs-bedtime) if you are also taking these other medications. Ask your doctor or pharmacist how long you should wait between doses and for help finding a dosing schedule that will work with all your medications. Take this medication regularly to get the most benefit from it. To help you remember, take it at the same time each day if you are taking it once a day. If you are taking this medication only once a week, remember to take it on the same day each week. It may help to mark your calendar with a reminder. If your doctor has recommended that you follow a special diet (such as a diet high in [calcium](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-1575/calcium+oral/details)), it is very important to follow the diet to get the most benefit from this medication and to prevent serious side effects. Do not take other [supplements](https://www.webmd.com/men/video/lamm-supplements-diet)/ [vitamins](https://www.webmd.com/vitamins-and-supplements/lifestyle-guide-11/vitamin-expert) unless ordered by your doctor. If you think you may have a serious medical problem, get medical help right away. Side Effects [Vitamin D](https://www.webmd.com/vitamins-supplements/ingredientmono-929-vitamin+d.aspx?activeingredientid=929&activeingredientname=vitamin+d) at normal doses usually has no side effects. If you have any unusual effects, contact your doctor or [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions) promptly. If your doctor has directed you to use this [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx), remember that your doctor has judged that the benefit to you is greater than the risk of side effects. Many people using this medication do not have serious side effects. Too much [vitamin D](https://www.webmd.com/vitamins-and-supplements/video/vtamin-d-and-your-health) can cause harmful high [calcium](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-1575/calcium+oral/details) levels. Tell your doctor right away if any of these signs of high vitamin D/ [calcium](https://www.webmd.com/food-recipes/ss/slideshow-gourmet-calcium) levels occur: [nausea](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-nausea-vomiting)/ [vomiting](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-nausea-vomiting), [constipation](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-constipation), loss of appetite, increased thirst, increased urination, mental/mood changes, unusual tiredness. A very serious [allergic reaction](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/allergic-reaction-causes) to this drug is rare. However, get medical help right away if you notice any symptoms of a serious [allergic reaction](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/anaphylaxis-15/slideshow-allergy-triggers), including: [trouble breathing](https://www.webmd.com/lung/breathing-problems-causes-tests-treatments). This is not a complete list of possible side effects. If you notice other effects not listed above, contact your doctor or pharmacist. In the US - Call your doctor for medical advice about side effects. You may report side effects to FDA at 1-800-FDA-1088 or at www.fda.gov/medwatch. In Canada - Call your doctor for medical advice about side effects. You may report side effects to Health Canada at 1-866-234-2345. Precautions Before taking [vitamin D](https://www.webmd.com/vitamins-supplements/ingredientmono-929-vitamin+d.aspx?activeingredientid=929&activeingredientname=vitamin+d), tell your doctor or [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions) if you are allergic to it; or to other [vitamin D](https://www.webmd.com/vitamins-and-supplements/video/vtamin-d-and-your-health) products (such as calcitriol); or if you have any other [allergies](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/allergy-relief-10/slideshow-allergy-myths-facts). This product may contain inactive ingredients (such as peanut/soy), which can cause allergic reactions or other problems. Talk to your pharmacist for more details. Before using this [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx), tell your doctor or pharmacist your medical history, especially of: high [calcium](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-1575/calcium+oral/details)/vitamin D levels (hypercalcemia/hypervitaminosis D), products, chewable tablets, or dissolving tablets may contain sugar and/or aspartame. Liquid products may also contain alcohol. Caution is advised if you have [diabetes](https://www.webmd.com/diabetes/diabetes-health-check/default.htm), [liver](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/picture-of-the-liver) disease, phenylketonuria (PKU), or any other condition that requires you to limit/avoid these substances in your diet. Ask your doctor or pharmacist about using this product safely. Before having surgery, tell your doctor or [dentist](https://www.webmd.com/oral-health/oral-health-care-providers) about all the products you use (including [prescription drugs](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx), nonprescription drugs, and herbal products). During pregnancy, doses of vitamin D greater than the recommended dietary allowance should be used only when clearly needed. Discuss the risks and benefits with your doctor. This medication passes into [breast](https://www.webmd.com/women/picture-of-the-breasts) milk. Consult your doctor before breast-feeding. Interactions [Drug interactions](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/video/vd-0801-atsp-12) may change how your [medications](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) work or increase your risk for serious side effects. This document does not contain all possible drug interactions. Keep a list of all the products you use (including prescription/nonprescription drugs and herbal products) and share it with your doctor and [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions). Do not start, stop, or change the dosage of any medicines without your doctor's approval. Some products that may interact with this drug include: burosumab, phosphate binders. Check the labels on all your prescription and nonprescription/herbal products (such as antacids, [laxatives](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/chronic-constipation-7/laxative-safety), [vitamins](https://www.webmd.com/vitamins-and-supplements/lifestyle-guide-11/vitamin-expert)) because they may [calcium](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-1575/calcium+oral/details), [magnesium](https://www.webmd.com/diet/supplement-guide-magnesium), phosphate, or [vitamin D](https://www.webmd.com/vitamins-supplements/ingredientmono-929-vitamin+d.aspx?activeingredientid=929&activeingredientname=vitamin+d). Ask your pharmacist about using those products safely. [Vitamin D](https://www.webmd.com/vitamins-and-supplements/video/vtamin-d-and-your-health) is very similar to calcitriol. Do not use medications containing calcitriol while using vitamin D. This vitamin may interfere with certain lab tests (such as [cholesterol tests](https://www.webmd.com/cholesterol-management/tests-for-high-cholesterol-lipid-panel)), possibly causing false test results. Make sure lab personnel and all your doctors know you use this vitamin. Overdose If someone has overdosed and has serious symptoms such as passing out or [trouble breathing](https://www.webmd.com/lung/breathing-problems-causes-tests-treatments), call 911. Otherwise, call a poison control center right away. US residents can call their local poison control center at 1-800-222-1222. Canada residents can call a provincial poison control center. Symptoms of [overdose](https://www.webmd.com/mental-health/addiction/drug-overdose) may include: [seizures](https://www.webmd.com/epilepsy/understanding-seizures-basics), confusion, irregular heartbeat. Lab and/or medical tests (such as [calcium](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-1575/calcium+oral/details)/ [magnesium](https://www.webmd.com/diet/supplement-guide-magnesium)/phosphorus levels) should be done while you are taking this [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx). Keep all medical and lab appointments. Consult your doctor for more details. Foods rich in [vitamin D](https://www.webmd.com/vitamins-supplements/ingredientmono-929-vitamin+d.aspx?activeingredientid=929&activeingredientname=vitamin+d) include: fortified dairy products, eggs, sardines, [cod liver oil](https://www.webmd.com/vitamins-supplements/ingredientmono-1040-cod+liver+oil.aspx?activeingredientid=1040&activeingredientname=cod+liver+oil), chicken livers, and fatty fish. If you miss a dose, take it as soon as you remember. If it is near the time of the next dose, skip the missed dose. Take your next dose at the regular time. Do not double the dose to catch up. Store [vitamin D](https://www.webmd.com/vitamins-supplements/ingredientmono-929-vitamin+d.aspx?activeingredientid=929&activeingredientname=vitamin+d) products (except alfacalcidol) at room temperature away from light and moisture. Do not store in the bathroom. Store alfacalcidol drops in the refrigerator. Do not freeze. Keep all [medications](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) away from children and pets. Do not flush medications down the toilet or pour them into a drain unless instructed to do so. Properly discard this product when it is expired or no longer needed. Consult your [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions) or local waste disposal company.
